sen.j: 背奈 行文（せな の ゆきふみ、生没年不詳）は奈良時代の歌人、明経道。
sen.e: SENA no Yukifumi (year of birth and death unknown) was a kajin (waka poet) and a scholar of Myogyo-do (the study of Confucian classics), who lived during the Nara Period.
SENA no Yukifumi (year of birth and death unknown) was a kajin (waka poet) and a scholar of Myogyo-do (the study of Confucian classics), who lived during the Nara period.
sen.cmt: 不要なスペースを削除しました。period小文字にしました。
sen.e: SENA no Yukifumi (year of birth and death unknown) was a kajin (waka poet) and a scholar of Myogyo-do (the study of Confucian classics), who lived during the Nara period.
He was the son of SENA no Fukutoku.
He was the son of SENA no Fukutoku.
He was the son of SENA no Fukutoku.

sen.j: 武蔵国国司高倉福信の叔父とされる。
sen.e: He was said to be the uncle of Musashi no kuni kokushi (the provincial governor of Musashi Province), TAKAKURA no Fukushin.
He was said to be the uncle of Musashi no kuni kokushi (the provincial governor of Musashi Province), TAKAKURA no Fukushin.
He was said to be the uncle of Musashi no kuni kokushi (the provincial governor of Musashi Province), TAKAKURA no Fukushin.
He was ranked Shorokui (Senior Sixth Rank) and served at Daigaku-ryo (Bureau of Education under the Ritsuryo system).
He was ranked Shorokui (Senior Sixth Rank) and served at Daigaku-ryo (Bureau of Education under the Ritsuryo system).
He was ranked Shorokui (Senior Sixth Rank) and served at Daigaku-ryo (Bureau of Education under the Ritsuryo system).

sen.j: 高句麗王族の渡来人背奈福徳の子。
sen.e: He was the son of SENA no Fukutoku, who was a toraijin (people from overseas, especially from China and Korea, who settled in early Japan and introduced Continental culture to the Japanese) coming from the Royal family of Goguryeo (kingdom of Korea).

He was the son of SENA no Fukutoku, who was a toraijin (people from overseas, especially from China and Korea, who settled in early Japan and introduced Continental culture to the Japanese) coming from the Royal family of Goguryeo (kingdom of Korea).

He was the son of SENA no Fukutoku, who was a toraijin (people from overseas, especially from China and Korea, who settled in early Japan and introduced Continental culture to the Japanese) coming from the Royal family of Goguryeo (kingdom of Korea).

sen.j: 聖武天皇の功臣で、初め、武蔵国高麗郡に住した。
sen.e: He was Emperor Shomu's meritorious retainer, at first he was living in Koma Country, Musashi Province.
He was Emperor Shomu's meritorious retainer, at first he was living in Koma Country, Musashi Province.
He was Emperor Shomu's meritorious retainer, at first he was living in Koma Country, Musashi Province.

sen.j: のちに上洛し、学問的教養を生かして貴族となった。
sen.e: Afterwards, he went up to Kyoto and gained the peerage, using his academic cultural background as advantage.
Afterwards, he went up to Kyoto and gained the peerage, using his academic cultural background as advantage.
Afterwards, he went up to Kyoto and gained the peerage, using his academic cultural background as advantage.

sen.j: 消奈行文大夫（せなのぎょうもんのまへつきみ）として、『万葉集』に1首と『懐風藻』に五言詩を2首残している。
sen.e: His poems were included in "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves) and "Kaifuso" (Fond Recollections of Poetry) with the name, SENA no gyomon no mahetsukimi (Writing master SENA); one waka poem in "Manyoshu", and two five-character-line poems in "Kaifuso."
sen.cmt: 消奈行文大夫（せなのぎょうもんのまへつきみ）→定訳不明・正式な読み方が不明です：SENA no gyomon no mahetsukimi (Writing master SENA) としました。
sen.e: His poems were included in "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves) and "Kaifuso" (Fond Recollections of Poetry) with the name, SENA no gyomon no mahetsukimi (Writing master SENA); one waka poem in "Manyoshu," and two five-character-line poems in "Kaifuso."
sen.cmt: コンマの位置を訂正しました。
sen.e: His poems were included in "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves) and "Kaifuso" (Fond Recollections of Poetry) with the name, SENA no gyomon no mahetsukimi (Writing master SENA); one waka poem in "Manyoshu," and two five-character-line poems in "Kaifuso."

sen.j: 奈良山の 児の手柏の 両面に かにもかくにも 佞人の徒 （『万葉集』（巻16-3836））
sen.e: Like trees of konotegashiwa (a specie of tree that was often used as a metaphor of two-sided person) in Mt. Nara, which have two faces, these means flatter two sides ("Manyoshu" Vol. 16-3836).
sen.cmt: 奈良山の 児の手柏の 両面に かにもかくにも 佞人の徒→「奈良山に生えるコノテガシワは面(おもて）が二つ。それと同じように、両方にへつらう心まがりの奴（やつ）らよ」をもとにしました。[http://ww.asahi.com/edu/student/manyou/OSK200911200006.html] 児の手柏→コノテガシワについては、異論があるようなので、名称を特定 (platycladus あるいは an evergreen coniferous tree)せず、konotegashiwa (a specie of tree that was often used as a metaphor of two-sided person) としました。
sen.e: Like trees of konotegashiwa (a specie of tree that was often used as a metaphor of two-sided person) in Mt. Nara, which have two faces, these means flatter two sides ("Manyoshu" Vol. 16-3836).
Like trees of konotegashiwa (a specie of tree that was often used as a metaphor of two-sided person) in Mt. Nara, which have two faces, these means flatter two sides ("Manyoshu" Vol. 16-3836).
